subject: Re: Reporting,trace messages, etc
msgSnippet: Hello Mr Rainsberger, Thanks for your suggestion. ... some ... as ... only ... you to ... I like your suggestion of adding to the TestListener. I am interested
messageBody:
Hello Mr Rainsberger,

Thanks for your suggestion.

> >
> > I am starting to use JUnit and am relatively new to it. After
> >searching thru documentation, this news group and other sources,
some
> >issues still remain that I hope some of you can help answer.
> >
> > 1. We have a need to put some trace messages in the tests so
as
> >to know the progress of the test itself because each test can be
> >fairly timeconsuming. Is there a way to have these capture this
> >output for an individual test in the GUI-based TestRunner? I see
only
> >thing that is captured for each test on the UI are the assertion
> >failures.
>
> My guess is that if TestListener doesn't have something to allow
you to
> log progress messages, then you can easily add something to it.



I like your suggestion of adding to the TestListener. I am interested
in implementing this. But for this would I have to touch the JUnit
TestRunner source or do you think I can do it externally?






>
> > 2. I see that JUnitReport is used quite extensively with Ant.
> >>From what I learnt reading, it helps output TestResult in XML
format
> >and then one can translate it using XSLT. Know how one can use
that
> >without having to use Ant? Any resources on Net would be helpful.
>
> Hm. Your best bet is to look at the source of the JUnitReport task
and
> you should be able to tell, from that, how to use it outside Ant.
>


Ok! I will go and find the source for JUnitReport task and have a
look at it.



> > 3. I see JUnit is great for nesting sub-suites within a suite
and
> >thereby creating a tree of suites. But when it comes to test
results,
> >is there a way to get a breakup of which sub-suite had how many
> >failures from TestResult?
>
> If you want to map a TestSuite object to the collection of
> Failures/Errors generated by its tests, then your best bet is
likely to
> register an extra TestListener, which you can do by changing the
> TestRunner you usually use.
>


I have not played with the TestListener. So I will need to try it out.
But this suggestion would require TestRunner to be modified?



Thanks for your time,
Vern
